title: Is it legal to transfer debt from one business closing down into a newly formed LLC?
question: There is nothing in the Operating agreement of the new LLC that acknowledges this transfer of debt, yet the accountant put it on the books for the majority shareholder who was the sole owner of the original DBA. Is this legal?
question_tags: LLC (limited liability company),Business contracts,Business debt,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,LLC operating agreement
answers:
If you hire an attorney, your attorney might ask you "why" you're asking these questions.

Can debt be transferred? Yes. But unless the creditor agrees, the transfer of debt usually will not release the original debtor. In other words, the "majority shareholder" (let's call him Mr. X) can ask the newly formed LLC to accept his debt. The newly formed LLC can agree to take responsibility for it. The creditor, however, can still pursue Mr. X (or the former business, if the former business-not Mr. X individually-was the debtor).

Did the LLC accept the debt? Unknown. LLCs are attractive entities because they require less work (fewer mandatory meetings, records and reporting) than corporations. That does not mean, however, that they can do whatever they want. Maybe the accountant was trying to work some bookkeeping magic for Mr. X by putting the debt on the books. But if the LLC did not agree to accept the debt (or if the LLC took the debt without consideration, meaning Mr. X didn't give the LLC anything of value to take the debt), then the bookkeeping entry may have no legal effect. Keep in mind, the operating agreement is basically a contract defining how the LLC and its members will function. Acceptance of debt or other matters not in the ordinary course of business are likely to be found in the minutes, not in the operating agreement.

Any time you meet with an attorney, you should explain what you want (i.e., what is the motive behind your question). Legal rules generally won't change based on your motive, but the areas of focus may vary.
LLCs shield their members from personal liability. However, if there was a personal guarantee by the founder for any debt oft he LLC, an LLC offers no protection.

An attorney would probably need more facts to understand the reason for the transfer of the DEBT. Generally speaking, a transfer of ASSETS would not be legal if the purpose for the transfer was to hinder, delay or defraud creditors of the old business.

In California, a claim for "fraudulent transfer" is authorized by the Fraudulent Transfer Act, which is enacted at California Civil Code sections 3439 to 3439.12. Under Section 3439.04, a transfer is fraudulent as to a creditor, whether the creditor's claim arose before or after the transfer was made or the obligation was incurred, if the debtor made the transfer or incurred the obligation as follows:

1) With actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud any creditor of the debtor.

2) Without receiving a reasonably equivalent value in exchange for the transfer or obligation, and the debtor either:

A) Was engaged or was about to engage in a business or a transaction for which the remaining assets of the debtor were unreasonably small in relation to the business or transaction.

B) Intended to incur, or believed or reasonably should have believed that he or she would incur, debts beyond his or her ability to pay as they became due.

The purpose of California's Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (Civil Code sections 3439–3439.12) is "to prevent debtors from placing property which legitimately should be available for the satisfaction of demands of creditors beyond their reach...." (Chichester v. Mason (1941) 43 Cal.App.2d 577, 584.)

A fraudulent transfer or conveyance under the Act may be intentional (section 3439.04(a)(1)) or constructive (sections 3439.04(a)(2) and 3439.05):

An intentional fraudulent conveyance "is a transfer by the debtor of property to a third person undertaken with the intent to prevent a creditor from reaching that interest to satisfy its claim." (Yaesu Electronics Corp. v. Tamura (1994) 28 Cal.App.4th 8, 13.)

A constructive fraudulent conveyance has two forms. Civil Code section 3439.04(b) "provides that a transfer is fraudulent if the debtor did not receive reasonably equivalent consideration and either (1) Was engaged or about to engage in a business or a transaction for which the remaining assets of the debtor were unreasonably small in relation to the business or transaction; or [¶] (2) Intended to incur, or believed or reasonably should have believed that he or she would incur, debts beyond his or her ability to pay as they became due. Civil Code section 3439.05 provides that a transfer is fraudulent as to an existing creditor if the debtor does not receive reasonably equivalent value and was insolvent at that time or ... became insolvent as a result of the transfer...." (Mejia v. Reed (2003) 31 Cal.4th 657, 669–670 (internal quotations omitted).)
